{ "cells": [ { "cell_type": "code", "execution_count": 43, "metadata": {}, "outputs": [], "source": [ "import pandas as pd\n", "import numpy as np\n", "import matplotlib.pyplot as plt\n", "import math\n", "from sklearn import linear_model\n", "from sklearn.metrics import mean_squared_error\n", "from sklearn.metrics import r2_score\n", "import pprint as pp" ] }, { "cell_type": "code", "execution_count": 44, "metadata": {}, "outputs": [], "source": [ "def akaike_inf_crit(k,y_test,y_pred):\n", " residue = y_test - y_pred\n", " sse = sum(residue**2)\n", " return (2 * k + len(y_test) * math.log(sse))\n", " " ] }, { "cell_type": "code", "execution_count": 45, "metadata": {}, "outputs": [], "source": [ "def model_pred_eval(y_pred,y_test,name='Model1'):\n", " stats_dict={}\n", " error = abs(y_pred - y_test)\n", " stats_dict['mean_abs_error']=[np.mean(error)]\n", " stats_dict['median_abs_error']=[np.median(error)]\n", " stats_dict['median_accuracy']= [100 - np.median(100 * (error/y_test))]\n", " stats_dict['R2']=[r2_score(y_test,y_pred)]\n", " stats_dict['RMSE']=[math.sqrt(mean_squared_error(y_test,y_pred))]\n", " stats_dict['min_error']=[error.min()]\n", " stats_dict['max_error']=[error.max()]\n", " return pd.DataFrame.from_dict(stats_dict,orient='index',columns=[name])" ] }, { "cell_type": "code", "execution_count": 46, "metadata": {}, "outputs": [], "source": [ "def trim_axs(axs, N):\n", " \"\"\"little helper to massage the axs list to have correct length...\"\"\"\n", " axs = axs.flat\n", " for ax in axs[N:]:\n", " ax.remove()\n", " return axs[:N]" ] }, { "cell_type": "code", "execution_count": null, "metadata": {}, "outputs": [], "source": [ "\n" ] }, { "cell_type": "markdown", "metadata": {}, "source": [ "# Chemical Informatics\n", "Lennart Gundelach, June 2019, Oxford TMCS" ] }, { "cell_type": "markdown", "metadata": {}, "source": [ "# Introduction\n", "This assignment is " ] }, { "cell_type": "markdown", "metadata": {}, "source": [ "## Data Pr-Processing" ] }, { "cell_type": "code", "execution_count": 47, "metadata": {}, "outputs": [], "source": [ "df = pd.read_csv('../data/raw/training_subset.csv')\n", "clean_test = pd.read_csv('../data/processed/test_subset.csv')\n", "target = 'S0 (mM)'\n", "y_test = clean_test.loc[:,target].values \n", "y = df.loc[:,target].values" ] }, { "cell_type": "markdown", "metadata": {}, "source": [ "# Multiple Linear Regression" ] }, { "cell_type": "markdown", "metadata": {}, "source": [ "## Investigating linear correlation of each descriptor to S\n", "We begin by analyzing to what extent each predictor is linearly correlated to the solubility. This will allow identification of potential candidate predictors for multiple linear regression. Below, the pair wise linear regressions are plotted in order to visually inspect the data. Furthermore, the R2 value for each linear regression is shown in the title of each plot. The R2 value is the coefficient of determination and describes the proportion of the variance in the dependent variable which is predictable from the independent variables. A value close to 1 indicates a strong fit of the regression model to the data set and a low or negative value indicates a poor fit. In the plots below, none of the descriptors exhibit a strong linear correlation to solubility.
